articles.headline: U.S. to Recognize Jerusalem as Israel’s Capital, Trump Says, Alarming Middle East Leaders
articles.snippet: Igniting fears of violence in the region, President Trump’s decision could derail any peace initiative, Arab and European leaders warn.
articles.abstract: Igniting fears of violence in the region, President Trump’s decision could derail any peace initiative, Arab and European leaders warn.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump plans to recognize Jerusalem as the capital of Israel and move the American Embassy there, upending nearly seven decades of American foreign policy and potentially destroying his efforts to broker peace between Israel and the Palestinians.
articles.byline: By Mark Landler and David M. Halbfinger

articles.headline: Inside China’s Big Tech Conference, New Ways to Track Citizens
articles.snippet: The technologies for tracking citizens, and their wide acceptance in China, were on display at the World Internet Conference.
articles.abstract: The technologies for tracking citizens, and their wide acceptance in China, were on display at the World Internet Conference.
articles.lead_paragraph: WUZHEN, China — An artificial intelligence company touted a robot that could help doctors with diagnoses. A start-up displayed a drone designed to carry a single passenger 60 miles per hour.

articles.headline: The New ‘60 Minutes’ Book Has a Troubled History
articles.snippet: Jeff Fager, the show’s executive producer, took over the project after the original author asked about women in the “60 Minutes” workplace.
articles.abstract: Jeff Fager, the show’s executive producer, took over the project after the original author asked about women in the “60 Minutes” workplace.
articles.lead_paragraph: Jeff Fager, the executive producer of “60 Minutes,” took over the writing of a book on the CBS show’s 50-year history after objecting to the direction of the original author’s research, according to three people familiar with how the book came to be.
articles.byline: By John Koblin and Michael M. Grynbaum

articles.headline: Consumer Bureau’s New Leader Steers a Sudden Reversal
articles.snippet: The Consumer Financial Protection Bureau’s new acting director has suspended or softened several investigations and lawsuits. Some employees are quietly resisting.
articles.abstract: The Consumer Financial Protection Bureau’s new acting director has suspended or softened several investigations and lawsuits. Some employees are quietly resisting.
articles.lead_paragraph: The defanging of a federal consumer watchdog agency began last week in a federal courthouse in San Francisco.
articles.byline: By Jessica Silver-Greenberg and Stacy Cowley

articles.headline: Trump’s Endorsement of Roy Moore Points Up a G.O.P. Problem: Chaos
articles.snippet: President Trump’s impulsive, improvisational political style is preventing the Republican Party from establishing a true organization for the coming midterm elections.
articles.abstract: President Trump’s impulsive, improvisational political style is preventing the Republican Party from establishing a true organization for the coming midterm elections.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump’s sudden decision on Monday to endorse Roy S. Moore and direct the Republican National Committee to restore funding for the embattled Senate candidate in Alabama undercut party officials who have disavowed him.
articles.byline: By Jonathan Martin and Maggie Haberman

articles.headline: Conservative Groups Seeking Support for Tax Cuts Find It a Hard Sell
articles.snippet: Groups like the Koch-funded Americans for Prosperity are trying to convince ordinary Americans that this is good for them too.
articles.abstract: Groups like the Koch-funded Americans for Prosperity are trying to convince ordinary Americans that this is good for them too.
articles.lead_paragraph: MIAMI — A dozen high school students working for Americans for Prosperity, the conservative political network funded by Charles G. and David H. Koch, fanned out across the Little Havana neighborhood one day last week to make the case that the Republican tax bill was something to get excited about.

articles.headline: The Hidden Player Spurring a Wave of Cheap Consumer Devices: Amazon
articles.snippet: Numerous electronics brands have sprung up offering inexpensive gadgets. Here’s how Amazon enables them, and how other brands may copy that success.
articles.abstract: Numerous electronics brands have sprung up offering inexpensive gadgets. Here’s how Amazon enables them, and how other brands may copy that success.
articles.lead_paragraph: A few weeks ago, Wyze Labs, a one-year-old start-up in Seattle, sent me its first gadget to try. It’s a small, internet-connected video camera, the kind you might use for security or to keep tabs on your dog or your baby.

articles.headline: Trump Calls Jerusalem Plan Step Toward Peace, but It Puts Mideast on Edge
articles.snippet: An Israeli minister said moving the U.S. Embassy to Jerusalem would be “destiny.” The leader of Hamas called it “an unaccountable gamble.”
articles.abstract: An Israeli minister said moving the U.S. Embassy to Jerusalem would be “destiny.” The leader of Hamas called it “an unaccountable gamble.”
articles.lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — Palestinians burned photos of President Trump in Gaza, and the walls of the Old City were illuminated with the American and Israeli flags on Wednesday, as Mr. Trump made good on his campaign pledge to recognize Jerusalem as Israel’s capital.
articles.byline: By David M. Halbfinger, Mark Landler and Isabel Kershner

articles.headline: California Fires Enter the Heart of Los Angeles
articles.snippet: A brush fire erupted near the Getty Museum before dawn on Wednesday, while a much larger fire continued to rage out of control in the Ventura area.
articles.abstract: A brush fire erupted near the Getty Museum before dawn on Wednesday, while a much larger fire continued to rage out of control in the Ventura area.
articles.lead_paragraph: For the latest news on the wildfires, read our Thursday live updates here.
articles.byline: By Jennifer Medina and Richard Pérez-Peña
